And your last one - a Puccini opera set in Japan.
Madame Butterfly.
There you go.
Just knocked them out of the park.

Bang, bang, bang.
Well done.

For playing the puzzle today, you get a WEEKEND EDITION lapel pin, puzzle books and games.
You can read all about it at our website npr.org/puzzle.
And before we let you go, David, where do you hear us?
I'm a longtime sustaining member of WHYY 91FM in Philadelphia.
David Hodges of Collingswood N.J.
Thanks so much for playing the puzzle, David.
It was a pleasure and an honor.
Thank you.
OK, Will, what's up for next week?
Yes.
This week's challenge comes from listener Ed Pegg Jr., who runs the website mathpuzzle.com.
The word ""sort"" has an unusual property.

The first letter, S, is found inside the word ""first."" The second letter, O, is found inside ""second."" The third letter, R, is found inside ""third,"" and the fourth letter, T, is found inside ""forth."" Think of a familiar three-word phrase in 10 letters that has the same property in which every letter in the phrase is found inside its corresponding ordinal.
And here's a hint - it's something most people have, lose and regain.
What is it?
So again, a familiar three-word phrase in 10 letters in which every letter in the phrase is found inside its corresponding ordinal.
And it's something most people have, lose and gain again.
What is it?
OK, when you've got the answer, go to our website.
It is npr.org/puzzle.
And click on that submit your answer link.
Limit yourself to one entry per person, please.
Our deadline for those entries is Thursday, May 29 at 3 p.m. EDT.
Don't forget a phone number where we can reach you at about that time because if you're the winner, then we give you a call.
And then you get to play on the air with the puzzle editor of the New York Times.
And he is WEEKEND EDITION's puzzle master, Will Shortz.
Thanks so much, Will.
Thanks, Rachel.
I'm Ed Gordon, and this is NEWS AND NOTES.
For a recap of this week's news from inside the Beltway, we go now to NPR's senior correspondent Juan Williams in our Political Corner.
Juan?
Thanks, Ed.
I'm joined by Donna Brazile, former campaign manager for Democratic Presidential nominee Al Gore in 2000.
Ms. Brazile now runs her own political consulting firm here in Washington.
Also with us, the Reverend Joseph Watkins, a member of the Government Relations Group at Buchanan Ingersoll.
Reverend Watkins is a member - or was a member -of the first President Bush's White House staff.
Thank you both for joining us on Political Corner.
Thank you, Juan.
Delighted.
Delighted to be here.
General Michael Hayden, number two man now at the National Intelligence Directorate, has been nominated to be CIA Chief.

But just last week, USA Today revealed that the government has been collecting vast storehouses of phone calls, not necessarily the content of the calls or the names of the people, but just all the phone numbers.
Joe Watkins, does this mean that there's any chance that Hayden might not be confirmed?
I think Michael Hayden will be confirmed.
We do live in a post-9/11 world where we have this task before us to catch the terrorists before they get us.
This is not a war where the enemy is wearing a certain kind of uniform, or coming from one country, or are easily identified.
These are people who wish not to be identified, and who come in as thieves in the night to destroy our country.
And so, other means of rooting them out have to be used.

And so, I think that what's happening certainly is going to be debated in the public arena, and somewhat in the courts as well, but I think that the efforts that are being made by NSA and others to catch these terrorists are going to be meaningful.
And they're going to ultimately keep all of us safe.
And that's what it's all about, is making sure that Americans are safe.
Now, Donna Brazile, the polls are kind of, you know, all over on this.
But I did see two polls -one from Newsweek one from USA Today - both indicated that a majority of Americans were concerned about the idea that their civil liberties were being violated.

But, one, does Michael Hayden get confirmed even though he didn't tell people on Capital Hill about this program - and two, even if he is confirmed, is this a problem going down the line for the Bush administration?
I think Mr. Hayden is going to have a tough time on camera and off camera.

Look, originally, he told us back in January when the initial warrant-less wiretap program was revealed, don't worry, because the administration is only targeting those international calls coming in to the country.
Basically, unless we had ties to the terrorists, don't worry.
Now we're learning that perhaps this program was more expansive.
And once again, it raises the question of legality.
Did the administration have the legal authority to wiretap or to get all of these phone records?
What are they doing with these phone records?
Mr.
Hayden, who was the Director of the National Security Agency for a long period of time - from 1999 to 2005 - he oversaw this program.
He will have to tell those members of Congress what is going on.
I'm concerned about privacy.
I'm also concerned about the legality of this.
And unless Mr. Hayden comes forward and tells the truth and tells us more about this program, I think many senators will vote to reject his nomination.
At some point, Congress has got to set down a marker.
Otherwise, they are violating their constitutional responsibility to provide oversight of the federal government.
Congress cannot continue to hide behind the shadows while the Bush administration takes away more and more of our rights.
Right.
That's under the guise of national security and fighting terrorism.
And one last question for you, Joe Watkins.
In fact, the numbers -the President's numbers among conservatives - are going down.
So, is it possible that now some on the Senate might feel they have the latitude to challenge the president, to make a statement, in terms of opposing Gen.
Hayden?
The Ozark and Washtaw National Forests cover 2.6 million acres in Arkansas.
According to a federal draft proposal, this remote wilderness could be a perfect place for the panthers to live.
Back in 1980, there were fewer than 30.
Now, as many as 100 panthers live in a protected habitat near Orlando.
But encroaching development in south Florida is crowding that habitat, so U.S.
Fish and Wildlife managers say its time to expand their range.
Panther recovery team member Paul Souza is a deputy field supervisor in the south Florida division.
The Ozarks was one of the locations that was identified in looking at potential habitat areas that could potentially support a panther population.
But truly, my feeling is, without public support, reintroduction efforts would not be successful.
Such public support would have to come from the Arkansas Game and Fish Commission.
Deputy Director David Goad says when the Panther Recovery Team approaches them for an opinion, they'll object to the plan.
Well, I promise it don't look all that good.
It does not.
I mean, I hate it, I hate that we live in that kind of a world.
You know, a hundred years ago, or maybe even 50 years ago, it might not have been that big an issue.
It might've could've pulled it off.
But you hear the horror stories out in California about the mountain lions that are snatching folks off the bike paths.
Since 1994, there's been four documented fatal mountain lion attacks in California.
However, scientists say the eastern panther is a different breed of cat.
It's smaller than the western mountain lion, has reddish-gray fur, and does not prey on humans.
Darrell Land is a panther biologist with the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission.
Florida panthers prey primarily on two large critters down here: white-tailed deer, and feral hogs.
